title: Invisible Women
summary:
Key ideas:
- The entry of women into the workforce produced little effect on US GDP even though the number of women in the workforce increased significantly over a period of 50 years.
- The author questions why the GDP trend did not deviate upward from 1935 to 1985 when almost 50% more people, predominantly women, entered the workforce.
- The author explores possible solutions to this question, including false GDP data, low-resolution GDP data, unpaid labor in the home, and all gains being made by women coming from men's pockets.

Key learnings:
- GDP only counts paid-for goods and services, not unpaid labor or benefits of putting women to work.
- Despite women increasing the labor supply by 50%, their entrance into the workforce did not change the demand for labor.

Key questions:
- Why did the entry of women into the workforce produce little effect on US GDP?
- Did women entering the workforce drive down male wages?
